metadata.description: Complete health, fitness, and transition tracking data

logging_conventions.timezone: Pacific Time (PT) - UTC-8/UTC-7. User is located in Seattle, Washington, US.
logging_conventions.late_night_entries: When logging late at night or in early morning hours (after midnight), assume entries are for the previous calendar day unless explicitly stated otherwise. If it's 2AM Tuesday, treat food/activity logs as Monday's data by default.

chocolate.notes: Assume this brand/type unless otherwise specified

chili.recipe_notes: Uses 4 Tbsp olive oil and adds 2 dates

smoothie.notes: This is the default smoothie unless stated otherwise

oatmeal.notes: This is the default breakfast unless stated otherwise

soy_milk.notes: Always refers to Silk unsweetened unless otherwise specified

changes: Stopped tracking micronutrients (potassium, magnesium, omega-3, calcium, iron) in daily logs and food events; track calories, macros, and fiber only.
Added graded daily 'healthy' flag to capture food-quality patterns (plant-forward meals, takeout/snacks load, meat heaviness).
Preserved existing micronutrient history by moving prior micronutrient values into micronutrients_legacy objects.

cardio_endurance.item: Optional short intervals (8â€“15 min total work; controlled)
Recovery walk / very easy movement (20â€“30 min)

lower_body_strength.item: Glutes/hips strength day (hip thrust/bridge + squat pattern)
Glutes/hips shaping day (hinge + higher-rep pump work)
Glute med + hip stability mini-session (10â€“15 min)
Keep upper-body loading minimal (no heavy presses/pulls; use only daily-life movement)

core_back_health.item: Core anti-rotation (Pallof press or carry) (8â€“12 min)
Back-friendly posterior chain accessory (light back extension or hip hinge pattern) (2â€“3 easy sets)
Daily posture break: 2â€“3 minutes of gentle thoracic opening

goals: Calm, consistent surplus with minimal day-to-day swings
Keep protein adequate and diffuse (not spiked or lean/isolated)
Pair protein with fats and carbs; avoid muscle-preserving signaling patterns
Include adequate dietary fat to support hormonal environment
Maintain fiber and micronutrient intake for cardiovascular/heart health
Avoid restriction cycles that increase stress or disrupt redistribution

protein.philosophy: Keep protein adequate but diffuse (avoid spiking or relying on lean/isolated sources). Prefer pairing with fats and carbs and avoid patterns that feel like deliberate muscle-preservation signaling.
key_factors: Distribution: spread across meals rather than concentrated
Pairing: consumed with fats and carbs, not lean/isolated
Timing: avoid acute protein immediately post-workout
Context: combined with no upper-body training stimulus

calories.philosophy: Keep a calm, consistent surplus to support recovery and estrogen-driven changes. Primary improvement focus: reduce volatility (avoid oscillating between low days and large surpluses). Use floors and a soft ceiling most days; if you go high one day, do not compensate with a low dayâ€”return to your base day.

add_on_system.principle: Keep a stable base day; add calories based on training load instead of reinventing the whole day.
notes: Above 3200 is fine when intentional (social dinner, long hike, double-run day).
If you go high one day, do NOT compensate with a low day; return to the base day.

carbs.philosophy: Neutral or positive. Primary fuel for endurance and lower-body training. No distinction between complex and simple.

fat.philosophy: Supportive. Essential for hormone production, fat-soluble vitamins, and calorie intake without protein.

evaluation_criteria.green: Calories mostly 2600-2900 (or within plan floors/ceiling), with training days â‰¥2500 and no days <2400; protein ~100-120g when diffuse/fat-paired; fiber â‰¥28g most days. 'Healthy' flag can be ðŸŸ¢ or ðŸŸ¡.
evaluation_criteria.yellow: Calories outside 2600-2900 or â‰¥3200 (especially if unplanned), or fiber <28g; still no restriction pattern. Often coincides with a ðŸŸ¡ healthy flag.
evaluation_criteria.red: Any restriction-pattern day (<2400 without illness/intentional exception), repeated low-energy days, or patterns that reintroduce muscle-preservation signaling (e.g., repeated lean protein spikes + upper-body loading). Often coincides with âŒ healthy flag.

fiber.philosophy: Fiber is the one quantitative 'quality proxy' you track. It tends to correlate with plant intake and steadier appetite/energy.

scale.ðŸŸ¢: Healthy day: at least one clearly plant-forward meal (beans/lentils/tofu/veg-heavy), snacks not dominant, takeout limited; overall feels nutrient-dense.
scale.ðŸŸ¡: Mixed: some plants are present but the day is noticeably takeout/snack heavy and/or meat-forward; still adequate overall.
scale.âŒ: Not healthy: day is dominated by takeout/ultra-processed snacks and/or heavy meat with little plant-forward food; low fiber often accompanies this.
scale.âšª: Not rated / incomplete day (e.g., still logging).

examples_not_healthy: low micronutrient intake (captured now via quality judgment rather than numbers)
notes: This flag is descriptive, not moral.
Expect plenty of ðŸŸ¡ days; occasional âŒ days are normal.
You'll likely refine this rubric over time.

fitness_philosophy.big_picture: Selective change over time with health and longevity as non-negotiables. Create permissive conditions for long-term feminization: strong estrogen/suppressed testosterone, adequate energy, low systemic stress, and sustainable training that does not interfere with gradual change.
physique_goals: Allow upper-body muscle to gradually atrophy through disuse (minimize upper-body hypertrophy stimulus)
Support slow, estrogen-driven fat redistribution toward hips/thighs/chest
Improve shoulder-to-hip visual balance via glute/hip development and softness (not extreme dieting)
Maintain or subtly grow glutes and hips for proportion
Reduce hypervigilant self-scrutiny; prioritize stability over rapid change
Avoid systemic stress patterns that provoke rebound or stagnation

cardio.approach: Regular aerobic work (running, cycling, elliptical, walking) for cardiovascular health, recovery, and fat-friendly stress
cardio.intensity: Managed to avoid injury and excessive cortisol
timing_rules: Avoid stacking the hardest run (quality/threshold) and the hardest glute session back-to-back when possible.
Aim for 24â€“48 hours between the hardest endurance session and the hardest glute session when possible.
If cardio is needed near a hard glute day, prefer low-eccentric options (elliptical/bike/walk) over hard running.

strength.lower_body: Glute-focused with minimal systemic stress: 1 hard glute day + 1 shaping day. Hard day: controlled hypertrophy, no failure. Shaping day: still low fatigue, but include 2â€“4 hard sets (RIR ~1â€“3) of a hip-dominant glute-max movement (hip thrust/bridge, glute-biased back extension, or similar) before pump work. Add 1 micro-dose glute-med session (10â€“15 min; 2â€“3 sets abduction/lateral pattern) weekly if recovery is good. Optional third session only as a true outlierâ€”keep it easy and do not chase fatigue.
strength.upper_body: Intentionally minimized (avoid upper-body hypertrophy stimulus); allow atrophy via disuse
strength.quad_bias_note: If quad growth is not desired, bias programming toward hip-dominant patterns over heavy knee-dominant squatting.

mobility.target: Minimum viable: 10 minutes after 3 sessions/week (micro-dose). Ideal: 2 dedicated sessions/week if time allows.
mobility.approach: End-range loading (ATG split squats, loaded stretches) for tissue health. Addresses hip irritation noted in ballet.
implementation: Keep it short and frequent rather than waiting for a 'perfect' long session.
Prioritize hips/hip flexors + ankles/calves (supports running + ballet, protects the irritated hip).

other.ballet: Movement quality and nervous-system regulation, not training stress
other.climbing: Social and occasional, not a conditioning driver

health_priorities: Heart health via regular aerobic work
Joint health (hips, ankles, spine) and lower-back injury prevention
Mobility and controlled loading for tissue resilience
Emotional stability and sustainability over intensity

instructions: You classify a user's message for a health & fitness tracker.
The user has a single input box that can be used to log food, log an activity, or ask a question.
Choose exactly one intent: food, activity, question, or clarify.
If the message is ambiguous or could be multiple intents, ask a clarifying question instead of logging.
If there is an attached image and no clear question, prefer intent=food.
For activity intent, select one or more checklist items using the provided category + index.
If multiple activities are mentioned, return multiple selections.
For activity details, standardize to minutes and optional intensity.
If duration is unknown, set duration_min to null. If intensity is not mentioned, set it to null.
Put any remaining specifics (distance, location, modifiers) into notes.
If the user appears to be answering a prior clarification, use the chat history to map to the right item.
Return only the JSON that matches the provided schema.
You are a helpful assistant for a personal health & fitness tracker.
The user is tracking trans feminization goals with a calm-surplus diet and endurance-biased fitness.
Use the provided JSON context as the source of truth. Do not invent dates, totals, or events.
If the context does not contain the information needed, say what is missing and ask a clarifying question.
When referencing numbers, use the units as shown (kcal, g, mg).
Be concise and supportive; prefer short actionable next steps.
You write the assistant response immediately after a meal entry is logged.
Return only JSON matching the schema.
The final chat response supports markdown.
Do not literally repeat or quote the user's raw meal description text.
Use bold markdown for food names and gram/portion amounts when available, for example **salmon (120 g)**.
confirmation: clearly confirm the entry was logged (date/source). Keep it concise.
nutrition_summary: use a short markdown bullet list with calories and macros (carbs, fat, protein) and fiber for both the logged meal and current day totals.
day_fit_summary: briefly explain how this fits into the day using available goals, activity context, and what else has been eaten.
nutrition_summary and day_fit_summary must read as separate paragraphs in the final message.
Tone must be helpful, concise, and non-judgmental.
Set followup_question only if one specific answer is required to materially improve nutrition accuracy.
Do not ask routine or optional follow-up questions; if accuracy would not meaningfully change, set followup_question to null.
Do not invent missing data. If data is missing, say so briefly in day_fit_summary.
